**Course Description and Objectives:**

This two-semester seminar is designed to help MA students become better academic writers. We will develop several different skills that are necessary for academic writing at the MA level: (1) interpreting literature, or “primary sources,” through close reading; (2) interpreting academic scholarship or “secondary sources”; (3) conducting research and documenting sources; and (4) bringing together interpretations of primary and secondary sources into a well-organized academic essay. This course takes a team-based approach, with students working together with professors and peers to improve their writing through several different writing-based activities and workshops. In the first semester, students will complete several short writing assignments with the ultimate goal of writing a very short academic paper; in the second semester, students will work toward writing (or substantially revising) a complete academic essay and sharing their work in a conference presentation.

**Requirements:**

1.  Grading policy for the fall semester:

Attendance & participation 20%; Writing assignments 80%.

Two assignments of 850 words and the final assignment of 1800 words, a mini academic paper. The deadlines for the assignments will be posted on Moodle in week 2.   

1.  Punctuality in turning in your homework is required. 5 points per day will be deducted for late submissions. Exceptions are allowed only under emergency circumstances or with notification in advance.
2.  Any student who plagiarizes will fail the course. This includes self-plagiarism: you can _revise_ an essay/assignment that you have written for another course, but you cannot pass it off as a _new_ essay/assignment.

\* This is a one-year seminar for literature-track students in the English department; thus, **_the fall semester is a prerequisite._**

(e.g. abstract, introduction, conclusion)

**Finding Your “Niche,” Finding Your “Voice”: Doing a Literature Review and Engaging in Close Reading**

*   How to join a scholarly conversation on a topic? Or what does it mean to “join a scholarly conversation” when writing an academic essay?
